questions.question: How many layers are in the OSI model?
questions.explanation: The OSI model has 7 layers: Physical, Data Link, Network, Transport, Session, Presentation, and Application.

questions.question: What does a computer with IP address 169.254.x.x indicate?
questions.explanation: Windows assigns a link-local IP address (169.254.0.0 to 169.254.255.255) when DHCP server cannot be reached.

questions.question: Which layer of the OSI model handles data encryption?
questions.explanation: The Presentation layer (Layer 6) handles data encryption, compression, and format conversion.

questions.question: How many layers are in the TCP/IP model?
questions.explanation: The TCP/IP model has 4 layers: Network Access, Internet, Transport, and Application.

questions.question: What technology allows DSL to carry voice and data simultaneously?
questions.explanation: DSL uses filters to separate voice and data traffic on the same telephone line.

questions.question: What is the maximum cable length for Ethernet (100BASE-TX)?
questions.explanation: The maximum cable length for 100BASE-TX Ethernet is 100 meters (328 feet).

questions.question: Which protocol provides secure web browsing?
questions.explanation: HTTPS uses SSL/TLS encryption to provide secure web browsing and must be specified for secure content.

questions.question: What is Power over Ethernet (PoE) used for?
questions.explanation: PoE allows devices like IP phones and wireless access points to receive power through the Ethernet cable.

questions.question: Which OSI layer is responsible for routing?
questions.explanation: The Network layer (Layer 3) handles routing and logical addressing (IP addresses).

questions.question: What happens when 802.11b and 802.11g devices are mixed in a WLAN?
questions.explanation: When older 802.11b devices are present, the entire network operates at the slower 802.11b speed for compatibility.

questions.question: What tool tests serial port communication?
questions.explanation: A loopback plug performs a loopback test to troubleshoot serial communication ports.

questions.question: What is the subnet mask for a Class C network?
questions.explanation: Class C networks use a default subnet mask of 255.255.255.0, providing 254 host addresses.

questions.question: Which port does HTTP use by default?
questions.explanation: HTTP uses port 80 by default for unencrypted web traffic.

questions.question: What device operates at Layer 2 of the OSI model?
questions.explanation: Switches operate at Layer 2 (Data Link) using MAC addresses to forward frames.

questions.question: Which cable type is immune to electromagnetic interference?
questions.explanation: Fiber optic cables use light instead of electricity, making them immune to electromagnetic interference.

questions.question: What is the purpose of DHCP?
questions.explanation: DHCP (Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol) automatically assigns IP addresses and network configuration to clients.

questions.question: Which wireless standard operates only in the 5GHz band?
questions.explanation: 802.11a operates exclusively in the 5GHz band, while 802.11b/g use 2.4GHz.

questions.question: What type of address is used at Layer 2?
questions.explanation: MAC (Media Access Control) addresses are used at Layer 2 (Data Link) for local network communication.

questions.question: Which protocol is connectionless at the Transport layer?
questions.explanation: UDP (User Datagram Protocol) is connectionless and doesn't guarantee delivery, unlike TCP.

questions.question: What is the private IP address range for Class A?
questions.explanation: Class A private IP addresses range from 10.0.0.0 to 10.255.255.255.

questions.question: Which device connects multiple network segments at Layer 1?
questions.explanation: A hub operates at Layer 1 (Physical) and broadcasts all data to all connected devices.

questions.question: What does NAT stand for?
questions.explanation: NAT (Network Address Translation) allows multiple devices to share a single public IP address.

questions.question: Which port does SSH use?
questions.explanation: SSH (Secure Shell) uses port 22 for encrypted remote access.

questions.question: What is the maximum speed of 802.11g?
questions.explanation: 802.11g has a maximum theoretical speed of 54 Mbps operating in the 2.4GHz band.

questions.question: Which command displays the IP configuration in Windows?
questions.explanation: ipconfig displays IP configuration information in Windows, while ifconfig is used in Linux/Unix.

questions.question: What does DNS resolve?
questions.explanation: DNS (Domain Name System) resolves human-readable domain names to IP addresses.

questions.question: Which cable category supports Gigabit Ethernet?
questions.explanation: Cat 5e (enhanced) and higher support Gigabit Ethernet speeds up to 1000 Mbps.

questions.question: What is the purpose of ARP?
options: Resolve IP addresses to MAC addresses
questions.explanation: ARP (Address Resolution Protocol) resolves IP addresses to MAC addresses for local network communication.

questions.question: Which topology has a single point of failure?
questions.explanation: Star topology has a single point of failure at the central device (hub/switch).

questions.question: What is the range of well-known ports?
questions.explanation: Well-known ports range from 0 to 1023 and are reserved for standard services.

questions.question: Which protocol is used for email retrieval?
questions.explanation: POP3 and IMAP are used for email retrieval, while SMTP is used for sending email.

questions.question: What does a /24 subnet mask represent?
questions.explanation: A /24 (CIDR notation) represents 24 network bits, equivalent to subnet mask 255.255.255.0.

questions.question: Which layer provides flow control and error correction?
questions.explanation: The Transport layer (Layer 4) provides flow control, error correction, and reliable data delivery.

questions.question: What is the maximum distance for multimode fiber?
questions.explanation: Multimode fiber typically supports distances up to 550 meters for Gigabit Ethernet.

questions.question: Which wireless security protocol is most secure?
questions.explanation: WPA2 (Wi-Fi Protected Access 2) provides the strongest security with AES encryption.
